title: R42583
content: Federal job training and employment programs aim to connect vulnerable youth to work and school. These young people are typically low-income with barriers to employment, such as dropping out of school or being in foster care. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides job training and related services for unemployed and underemployed individuals, including youth. Programs under WIA, such as Youth Activities, Job Corps, and YouthBuild, are carried out by the Department of Labor. These programs make up the federal job training system for youth. The federal job training system for youth includes programs like Youth Activities, Job Corps, and YouthBuild. These programs aim to connect youth to educational and employment opportunities, leadership development, and community service activities. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 provides funding for these programs, with potential reauthorization in the future. Relevant bills include H.R. 803 and S. 1356. The Workforce Investment Act of 2013 (S. 1356) includes various job training and employment services for youth, such as WIA Youth Activities, Job Corps, YouthBuild, Reintegration of Ex-Offenders, and Youth Opportunity Grants. Despite WIA's authorization expiring in FY2003, Congress continues to appropriate funds for youth job training programs. The Workforce Investment Act of 2013 included programs for youth job training and services in low-income communities. Despite WIA's authorization expiring in FY2003, Congress continues to fund youth job training programs, except for the Youth Opportunity Grants program. These programs aim to connect low-income youth with educational and employment opportunities, with specific focuses on high school dropouts, youth offenders, and those at risk of dropping out. The YouthBuild program targets high school dropouts and focuses on construction-related activities. Job Corps offers residential services along with employment and educational support. The Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program provides various activities for youth offenders and at-risk individuals, including mentoring and educational services. Funding for these programs is allocated differently, with DOL distributing funds to states based on a formula. The Department of Labor (DOL) funds various youth programs such as YouthBuild, Job Corps, and the Reintegration of Ex-Offenders program. Funding is allocated based on formulas to states, which then distribute funds to local Workforce Investment Boards (WIBs). DOL also partners with nonprofit and for-profit organizations to operate Job Corps centers and cooperates with the USDA Forest Service for Job Corps programs on USDA lands. The follow-up report analyzed the longer-term impacts of the program on earnings and employment rates 5 to 10 years after random assignment. Positive employment effects diminished, with similar rates and earnings between program and control groups. However, older youth aged 20-24 at the time of program application saw increased earnings.
